Battlefield 2042 is the latest installment in the long-running Battlefield franchise, developed by DICE and published by Electronic Arts. Set in a near-future world on the brink of collapse, it aims to deliver a high-stakes, large-scale first-person shooter experience. Marketed as a return to form after the disappointment of Battlefield V, it instead fell short of expectations - arguably becoming an even bigger misstep for the series.
As much as I‚Äôve enjoyed the game since Season 5, I still can‚Äôt recommend it. Sure, the updates have been solid - DICE fixed, reworked, and added a lot of content - but it shouldn‚Äôt have taken so many months to get here.
The game launched in a terrible state, comparable to the rocky premieres of Cyberpunk 2077 and Fallout 76. And even now, it still falls short in many areas when stacked against previous Battlefield titles. I do appreciate DICE‚Äôs commitment to improving the game - especially when you consider how quickly Battlefield V was abandoned - but it‚Äôs simply not enough.


Disappointingly, there's no campaign mode at all.


Conquest (64 and 128), Close Quarter Conquest (64), and Breakthrough (64) are really the only default game modes that matter. I personally play almost exclusively in CQC - it‚Äôs intense and fast-paced - but unfortunately, the map pool is limited to just three. If you're looking for more variety, larger maps, or vehicle gameplay, Conquest and Breakthrough still hold up well. No complaints from me on that front.
Occasionally, the game introduces special events with unique modes and rewards. While they can be hit or miss, they offer players a welcome change of pace and something fresh to experience.


Battlefield Portal is an incredible concept that ultimately suffered from a lack of new content. It lets players create custom matches with a wide range of gameplay options and share them with the community. Overall, it's a fantastic feature that deserves to be a staple in future Battlefield games.


Hazard Zone is essentially an extraction shooter, aiming to be a Tarkov-lite set in the Battlefield universe. Unfortunately, it failed to capture interest, and as a result, it faded away quickly.


I‚Äôm one of those players who couldn‚Äôt care less about the specialists. Do I think it was a bad idea that doesn‚Äôt fit the Battlefield formula? Absolutely. Does it make the game unplayable or even significantly less enjoyable? Not really.
On one hand, I like the idea of gadgets and unique traits for each operator, but on the other hand, it's a bit odd to see 20 Sundances in a single match. With a few adjustments, it could be a fun gimmick in future Battlefield games - just don't make it the core focus.


Gunplay is always subjective, so I won‚Äôt spend too much time on it. Personally, I enjoyed it. It‚Äôs casual and doesn‚Äôt demand much mental effort - perfect for players who don‚Äôt have the time to master every nuance of the game. Most of the weapons are easy to handle, meaning even with average aim, you can still find yourself topping the leaderboards.
The TTK (time to kill) feels solid overall - fast enough to be satisfying, with the exception of three or four guns. As a result, enemies rarely feel like bullet sponges. That said, there are still issues with hit registration, lag spikes, and occasional desyncs. These problems can make the TTD (time to death) feel frustrating at times, as you can be one-shotted without any chance to fight back. While these issues aren‚Äôt as prevalent on smaller maps, they become much more noticeable in matches with 128 players.


I don‚Äôt have much to say about the vehicles in BF2042, since I rarely use them. The controls feel clunky, the vehicles move awkwardly, and flying helicopters and jets isn‚Äôt all that satisfying.


There‚Äôs no server browser, and it‚Äôs hard to understand why DICE was so determined not to include it. It remains one of the dumbest decisions they made.


Compared to older Battlefield games, this one feels like a step backward. Rather than enhancing the existing systems to allow for more impactful destruction, they scaled it back. Even visually, the explosions and building demolitions lack the satisfying impact we‚Äôve come to expect.


The maps in Battlefield 2042 are a real mixed bag - some, like Spearhead, are solid, while others, like Kaleidoscope, miss the mark. The release maps were especially bad before their reworks. They were too large, too open, with vast flat terrains and hardly any cover. Thankfully, most of them are now at least playable.
It might be controversial (or maybe not?), but I genuinely think the later maps from the new seasons are fantastic. Redacted especially stands out - it's easily one of my all-time favorites in the Battlefield franchise.


I like the overall design of the HUD. It‚Äôs modern, minimalist, and provides all the essential information without cluttering the screen (for the most part). Unfortunately, the customization options are limited, so if you‚Äôre not a fan of the default HUD, you're pretty much stuck with it.
After several patches, the UI has become much more solid. The menus have been streamlined, and even something as simple as changing attachments is no longer a hassle.


In my opinion, the game looks (mostly) good. While the older maps could use some improvement - often feeling too clean and lacking in detail - the newer ones are visually stunning. Redacted is packed with incredible detail, while Exposure impresses with its breathtaking environmental design.
The dynamic weather is an impressive concept, but in the long run, it doesn‚Äôt quite deliver. While random tornadoes or sandstorms can add unpredictability to fights, they often don‚Äôt feel impactful enough. It would be better if these events were rarer but capable of causing real havoc on the battlefield.


Technically, the soundtrack isn't bad. It's solid electronic music with a subtle noise element. The problem, however, is that it doesn't suit the game. While it fits the theme, it doesn‚Äôt match the gameplay. What we need is something that hypes us up, something to pump adrenaline into our veins! This is an FPS, not a horror or sci-fi game.
The rest of the audio is decent. Nothing groundbreaking, but at least everything sounds as it should.


Performance heavily depends on the map and game mode you're playing. From my experience, fewer players usually means better FPS and less desync. That‚Äôs why I‚Äôve always avoided the 128-player mode - it‚Äôs essentially a technical nightmare. Interestingly, newer maps seem to be better optimized compared to the older or reworked ones.
There are still a fair number of bugs and glitches. Aside from major issues like wonky hit registration and lag spikes, there are also smaller problems - like falling under the map or encountering flying vehicles.
The game supports crossplay with consoles, but if you're not a fan, there's an option to disable it.

Battlefield 2042 Major Issues:

- Specialist system undermines traditional team play
- Oversized maps with poor flow and empty spaces
- Missing core Battlefield features at launch
- Simplified mechanics reduce tactical depth
- Disruptive weather effects hurt gameplay

What Went Wrong:

The departure from class-based gameplay to specialists fractured the series' signature teamwork. Maps feel stretched and lifeless despite the 128-player count, creating excessive downtime between engagements. The weather effects, while visually impressive, randomly disrupt tactical planning and gunfights.

Design Failures:

- Removal of scoreboard at launch
- Limited weapon selection
- Poor optimization and performance
- Lack of server browser
- Reduced environmental destruction

Impact on Gameplay:

The core Battlefield experience suffers from these fundamental changes. Gone are the strategic squad compositions and focused combat zones, replaced by lone-wolf gameplay and frustrating traversal times. The reduction in destruction and cover options limits the tactical options that made previous titles excel.

This entry marks a significant step backward for the franchise, moving away from the elements that made Battlefield unique in the FPS genre.

I understand why CoD has such a cult following. Gameplay is good, but not GREAT. The controls are very chunky/sloppy. Even low level AI can be hard to engage with when the game chooses to be laggy. Biggest issue here is bullet spread. To EA, every gun has the uncontrollable recoil of a 110 pound woman firing a 7.62 LMG standing. At approx 30 in game feet, the spread from a 5.56 rifle is 2-3 hits out of 10 rounds fired. Its just unrealistic.

Lobbies are few and far between. There is no feature in the game showing whats popular currently so you can join multiple matches and none of them launch. Player base is also massively inconsistent. Just because you had back to back matches at one time of day doesnt mean that anyone will be on the next day at the same time.

Weapons leveling/progression is REALLY bad. You get ONE of each weapon type to start unless you pay them for ELITE. Thats not worth it for a $60 game. Advanced Battlepass is at least forgiveable at $10/ea. Characters and skins are also bad. You get ONE operator for each class (class systems are a bad model for FPS games anyway, elite operators in the US military cross-train to do every job, not just a specification) and that one operator has a bunch of CoD-esque skins that are boring and not overly tactical or cool or fun, but a really bad mis-match of all 3.

Where this game shines is the modes. Its not perfect by any means, but the diversity of maps and capture-the flag type objectives is realistic to a military styled FPS. The CON of the modes is the imbalance of vehicles/positions. In some maps (Im looking at you, Caspian Border and Stranded) there are severe imbalances in the enemy AI and Vehicles that blatantly impact your teams ability to get the Win. On Stranded, the AI alone is able to hold off the enemy team and prevent progression at the very first capture mission, causing an immediate stalemate no matter now many of them your team kills. On Caspian Border, the RUS team gets a plane, and NONE of the available equipment, vehicles, or classes available to the USA team can down it. You will spend the entire match with your team spamming Stinger missiles only to have them all miss, cuz FLARES. The only aerial vehicle option for the USA is a Blackhawk, which is useless given its lack of air-to-air capabilities.

I wish I could write an accurate review after I played this game but I could not even get that far along. The first time I ran the game after installing the mandatory EA App (which installs automatically when you run the game) I was greeted with the startup image and then a black screen that rendered my entire computer unresponsive. Had to shut the whole thing down manually by holding the physical power button on the PC like a barbarian. Great start, I know.

So to even get the game to run I had to re-verify the integrity of the game files via the steam dialog. Then I google searched the issue (which is apparently well documented enough to have multiple web articles about it) and had to clear the cache by running the repair tool for the EA app. Then sign back into the EA app. After that I could finally get the game to run and it put me in the introductory bot match.

The bot match was fun while it lasted, I guess. Pretty standard FPS gunplay stuff, the enemies where a little more bullet spongey that I am used to but I am nothing if not adaptable. My favorite part was when I spawned into a tank and tried to take down this attack helicopter that was murdering us. I thought it was a pretty neat detail that the tank main cannon cannot actually aim very high off the ground. Very realistic, I had to finagle the whole tank onto a hill so I could line up a shot. The helicopter blew up my tank, and then my bot teammates took it down before I could try again. But it was an endearing experience to me.

Anyway that was the first and last match I actually got to play in the game. After it finished I got taken to the main menu and looked around at all the guns, characters, and classes. Then I decided to try and play a real match. It was Friday so the had some Breakthrough game mode front and center, I think it was supposed to be like a 36v36 type deal. Anyway the game found a match pretty quickly and I was all set to join. Except I never made it in. After the screen would change to start loading into the match the game would crash. All 6 times I tried. With no error code. Just closed the game by itself. I changed the graphics settings from Auto (Which set everything to Ultra because I don't play on a potato anymore) to high as some people on the EA website suggested after the second crash. Didn't help. One person said that they had good results with turning down their ram frequency from 3500 to 3466. I didn't do that because I am not gonna fiddle around with my bios setting to possibly, maybe be able to play this game. I don't do that kinda thing for any other game in my library, because all of those just work after I install them. I would understand if the makers of the game was like a small indie team of like 6 people or something. EA is most certainly not that.

My typical experience with this game is a 3-5 minute boot period, followed by a minute long queue, followed by a minute long loading screen, followed by an endgame screen because I got backfilled into a game that was ending, followed by another minute long queue (most lobbies do not persist between games), followed by another minute long loading screen, before finally beginning a game. I get a 'battlefield moment' once every few months, but otherwise I only play this game to turn my brain off, not when I actually want to have fun playing a well-made game. 90% of my sessions end in alt-f4s because I get killed by an enemy that hasn't loaded in and isn't visible, or I spawn in front of an enemy, or I get killed by a vehicle that can destroy all anti-vehicle projectiles which get near it, or for any other number of generally frustrating reasons. Very rarely do I actually get a real team vs team gunfight or experience any squadplay, and while these moments are enjoyable, they are only enjoyable because of the other players enabling it. I could have the same positive gameplay experiences in almost any other multiplayer game, but only in battlefield 2042 do I have so many negative experiences that are clear products of simple bad game design. In short, there are no positive experiences unique to 2042, and the sparseness of any fun gameplay makes it impossible to recommend this game. Play any other battlefield game and you'll get all of the good with less of the bad, and for much much cheaper.

God did I not want to put a negative review on this game.

A Terrible Beginning
Battlefield 2042 had a disastrous launch, sadly reminiscent of Cyberpunk 2077. The pervasive bugs, performance issues, and missing features left a deplorable first impression among players, especially casual players like myself.

Gradual Improvement
However, it must be acknowledged that the game has significantly improved with each update. The developers have worked hard to fix the initial errors, introduce new features, and enhance the overall experience. Today, Battlefield 2042 is much more enjoyable and visually pleasing (we're FAR from what we've seen in the reveal trailer tho). Despite these improvements, Battlefield 2042 still suffers from the negative reputation of its launch. Many casual players, including myself, haven't been able to forget this chaotic start. This negative perception persists, even though the game has made significant progress since then.

Another major negative point is the complete absence of a story mode, which is disappointing for a game of this price. For me, Battlefield 2042 is not worth its current price, especially when compared to previous games in the series. Unfortunately, this game cannot be considered a true Battlefield worthy of its name. Compared to Battlefield 3, which captivated me for days & days, Battlefield 2042 fails to offer the same level of satisfaction and depth.

I want to commend the developers' efforts to maintain the game. It's nice to see that they haven't abandoned the project. However, neither Call of Duty nor Battlefield can bring back the joy I used to feel. I even replayed Battlefield 3 recently to confirm that it's not just nostalgia.

After hours of gameplay, it's disappointing to realize that you've seen it all and there's nothing left to discover. It's unclear what direction the developers wanted to take or what they intended to achieve with this game.

In conclusion, although Battlefield 2042 is an acceptable game today, it is very far from the excellence of Battlefield 3 or even Battlefield 1. Unfortunately, it doesn't follow the Battlefield editorial line, leaving me with a negative opinion despite its improvements.

Honestly, I really want to like this game. There's parts of it that are so much fun, and some parts that are evocative of the nature of a Battlefield franchise game, but EA might as well be the mark of death for a developer to publish under. 2042 is still poorly optimized on a decent build and loads incredibly slow, and no amount of game integrity checks or hotfixes has ever gotten this game to run smoothly.

"But Ferret," I hear you say, "Have you ever tried (insert X fix here) to get your game to run better?" No, I've certainly tried, but moreover I should not have to rely on an external support network to fix a game that is still 60 USD 4 years after launch. I should not have to sit and wonder why even though I meet the 'recommended' specs, the game barely runs smooth on medium graphical settings.

Map design is poorly done and horrendously inconsistent whether you're conducting combat as a vehicle or foot-soldier, TTKs are wildly imbalanced, the Crysis-esque attachment system is cool, but clunky to use in overall gameplay, and some of the gadgets are just straight up stupidly imbalanced. Map destruction physics are all but non-existant at this stage, and it's really unfortunate to see that some of the series-defining features have been reduced to little more than a party trick gimmick.

Could I recommend this game on good faith? No. I wouldn't even do so on bad faith. EA themselves could pay me twice whatever they spent marketing this slop, and I'd sooner use it to run a campaign AGAINST the marketing of the game to the wider audience of the world simply because this game doesn't know what it wants to be. I'm not sure it's a Battlefield game, or a Call of Duty game, or a Squad, or an Arma, because it lacks so much of the identity of the games it tries to emulate and compete against that I'd sooner recognize it as any other game had it not had the Battlefield tag slapped onto it.

And that's the real crux of the issue. DICE has lost their way or lost good employees, and they've already more than moved on to the next Battlefield game, and I can only hope with a severely large dose of medical-grade copium that they can actually produce a game worthy of the title, but like any other AAA dev studio publishing under a AAA publishing label, we might as well start reducing the amount of A's in their promises to develop an experience and replace them with a couple S's.

The only thing this game is now is ASS. Not AAA. Not AAAA(although it certainly invokes the feeling of wanting to vocalize that in frustration), not even Indie. There are mods and early access games with more promise and passion than was put into this whole thing from start to finish, and the fact that this was a fun game at moments and points showed that it had potential that was promptly wasted by greedy corporate devs and publishers that don't know why games are called games.

They might waste the potential of a Battlefield game, and they're free to do so, but don't waste your money trying to see the light in this. Save it for anything else.

So, this is yet another game and franchise that was ruined by corporate greed and ambition. It had a rough start, with numerous bugs, missing features, and overall poor design decisions. I missed much of the initial chaos and played mostly after the major fixes, so my perspective might be a bit biased. However, when I finally tried it, the game was already fun and improved significantly over the years. They fixed and redesigned many problematic aspects, added new content, and ironed out most of the bugs. I didn't encounter any noticeable issues during my ‚âà70 hours of gameplay. The gameplay is solid now, definitely capable of delivering those classic battlefield‚Ñ¢ moments. It's just a shame that the destruction aspect was downgraded so much. Once a staple of the franchise, it's now taken a backseat. Environmental hazards like tornadoes are fun occasionally, but they should complement, not replace, the great destruction mechanics (and possibly Levolution also).

One aspect that is rarely mentioned is the potential of its theme and setting. Its uniqueness and potential were sadly overlooked, as it's essentially only represented by some text in the menus, overshadowed by cheesy, cringe-worthy character dialogues. Surprisingly, I found the music to be a highlight. It offers a unique and interesting take on Battlefield's iconic and beloved themes, composed by a really talented musician. Overall, it's a real shame. This game had potential, but it was undercooked and almost immediately disregarded. Support for Portal and BR modes was dropped almost from the start, and now the game itself is reaching its end. So, if you like Battlefield or multiplayer shooters in general, definitely give it a try while it's still possible, especially considering how cheap it can be now (or even free with an EA subscription).

Graphics and atmosphere
The graphics component of Battlefield 2042 is really impressive. Weather effects, destructibility and detailed maps create a unique atmosphere of large-scale military operations. Giant maps allow tactics to run wild, and dynamic battles involving up to 128 players provide continuous action.

Gameplay
One of the main advantages of the game is its gameplay. The introduction of new character classes has added variety to the gameplay. The perks and operatives system has also proved successful, allowing players to customize their characters to suit different game styles.

The individualization of the weapon was partially successful. Although new types of weapons sometimes displace the old ones in terms of accuracy, everyone will find something to their liking. Dynamic movement, complemented by short jerks and tackles, benefited the gameplay, making it smoother and more responsive.

Game Modes
Battlefield 2042 features a variety of modes, each offering a unique gaming experience. The classic "Breakthrough" mode brings players back to their favorite mass battles, and the Hazard Zone mode offers a more cooperative and strategic approach. Portal, in turn, allows you to enjoy maps from the old parts of the series with updated rules.

THE GOOD
This game has so much positive improvements it's close to meeting my deep rooted feelings for BF2.

The game modes are great, giving every variety of player type a version of the game that suits.

For those battle hardened franchise lovers looking for 64 player battles, there are plenty of options. And although some regions with some particular times may not suit for finding lots of players, in most games I tested there were a good number of humans to challenge my skills!

But for me the biggest win was the near instant, ease of selecting either the Conquest Solo/Co-op (very similar to BF2 flag captures) or the Breakthrough Solo/Co-op (push forward to ever moving front line targets) games.
Instantly enter the action against Bots, invite a few friends on EA to join and within about 30 seconds were were all out battling with ease and fun.

Bots can be quickly adjusted depending on the friends and their experience, and the maps are epic, in some cases enhanced version of tried but true BF3 map etc.

BF2 days rekindled. But as I said in my heart I recall fondly the BF2 skirmishes with my friends playing. With a quick EA login, setup a custom Portal experience, I create my favourite maps with my preferences for players, bot numbers, respawn timings etc. Took me about 5 minutes to setup a test Portal Custom game.

One friend trying to run me over with his T28 tank as I fled to my buddy picking me up in the LATV4 RECON to attack Delta1! Bots, bots, bots ‚Äì Thank the gaming gods I can load up Conquest or Breakthrough with a full server of bots and pretend it‚Äôs 2007. No toxic teammates screaming slurs, no campers, just me vs. the AI ‚Äì and they‚Äôre not complete potatoes either. It‚Äôs like therapy after a rough day.

Graphics are sexy af ‚Äì Some of the close-quarters maps are straight eye candy. That crisp, gritty detail paired with some nice lighting makes the firefights feel intense, especially in solo sessions.

Portal is a mad idea... ‚Äì It gives major throwback vibes. Setting up old-school rules, tweaking damage and weapons, mixing eras ‚Äì it‚Äôs a dream for creative players. But ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•, why is it so restrictive? If I want to make a 2-shot hardcore mode with XP and ribbons, let me live, DICE.

Solo content actually exists ‚Äì Unlike most shooters today that shove multiplayer down your throat, 2042 lets you go full lone wolf. With a weak player base in my area, that‚Äôs a huge win.

What kinda bugs me:

Bullet sponge nonsense ‚Äì I don‚Äôt know what these bots are made of, but eating 5+ 30mm cannon shots should turn anyone into salsa, not just make them flinch. Hit reg and damage needs a good ol‚Äô tuning fork.

Battlefield 2042 is a divisive topic for both long-time fans of the series, and for those on the outside looking in. The open tests and subsequent launch of the game were plagued by severe technical issues, a lack of content & polish, and a perceived 'perversion' of mechanics deemed integral to the core Battlefield experience. Despite that, rather than being left to rot, DICE has been slowly healing the game, allowing the small but dedicated community to thrive. I'll preface everything by saying that I am die-hard supporter of the franchise, and I have played extensive amounts of nearly every single Battlefield title- and for me personally, 2042 ranks alongside BF4 and BF1 at the very top of that list.

TL;DR - BF2042 is in a much better place than it was before thanks to a few years of steady content updates. It's a genuinely great Battlefield experience, with many innovative mechanics I hope are carried forward to future franchise entries.

‚Üì‚Üì‚Üì - Expanded discussion on a few points of pain.

1 - Criticism was levelled at the decision to substitute faceless soldiers for named Specialists, and dispensing with the four Class system of previous games. While I understand & share the trepidation at the label 'hero shooter', it was nowhere near as constrictive as that label typically implies. All Specialists were fully capable of utilising any and all gadgets and gear in the game- a change that was oddly disliked, and thus was rectified later in the game's lifespan; Specialists were divided into the four traditional Classes once again, with restrictions on what gear they were allowed to bring (aside from primary/secondary weapons).

2 - There was a definite drought of interactive content when the game first released; fewer weapons, maps, vehicles, gadgets, etc. I've seen arguments against the game that still use this rhetoric, unaware of the fact that 2042 now boasts a comparable amount of weapons and maps to any other entry- technically exceeding them, even- through the Portal game mode, which contains remastered maps and weapons from numerous previous games, all the way back to Battlefield 1942.

3 - The perennial issue of the modern gaming age is, for many people, the (often forced) implementation of micro-transactions and battlepasses. 2042 is certainly complicit in perpetuating this, but I believe you would be hard-pressed to find a frequently updated, PvP-centric multiplayer title that doesn't have some form of MTX or event pass system. That's not to say I condone it; I simply don't believe it's the cancer that some folks make it out to be, when the offerings are strictly cosmetic and entirely optional, which is the case for 2042. New weapons are introduced in the battlepass, yes, but they are on the free track to be earned by anyone- and if you miss out on a previous season's new gear items, you can simply earn them via assignments.

4 - The removal of the single-player campaign is perhaps the topic that disappoints me the most. This one stings. I always enjoyed playing through the campaigns of Battlefield and Call of Duty games, but always preferred the former. I even actually found myself in the minority of people who were happy with BF1's shift to War Stories- it allowed for the telling of many self-contained stories, with drastically different characters & settings (which I personally found to have much more replay value than the traditional long form campaigns of earlier titles). EA was unfortunately too concerned with transforming Battlefield into another Apex Legends (EA placing potential profits above making a good game or listening to fans? Shocker!), and DICE could likely do nothing but conform.

Battlefield 2042 is yet another example of the benefits to being prudent in the judgement of new games, *especially* AAA games; sadly, it seems to be the modern standard to release games in an unfinished state, and patching them up over time into something worth playing. That doesn't always happen- sometimes failed games are shot in the leg and left to die, with everything they could have been slowly bleeding out into the dirt. 2042 avoided this fate; it stumbled at first, but eventually it hit a steady stride and crossed the finish line. Even then, its reputation will likely never recover, and after the current season ends, it'll never have the chance again. If you've heard bad things but wanted to verify for yourself, or you played it a long time ago and haven't touched it since, I urge you to give it one last try. It won't be around for too much longer, and I for one think that's a damn shame.

Review of Battlefield 2042
Rating: 7/10

Pros:

Stunning Visuals and Immersive Sound Design
Battlefield 2042 excels in delivering breathtaking graphics and audio. The massive maps feel alive, with weather effects like tornadoes and sandstorms adding a thrilling dynamic. The sound design is top-notch, capturing the intensity of war with booming explosions and realistic weapon effects.

Massive Battles with Scale and Chaos
With matches supporting up to 128 players on next-gen platforms and PC, Battlefield 2042 successfully conveys the chaos of all-out warfare. The maps are diverse, ranging from urban centers to wide-open deserts, offering varied gameplay experiences.

Specialist System
The introduction of Specialists adds a new layer of strategy. Each Specialist has unique abilities and gadgets, allowing players to tailor their gameplay style and contribute more dynamically to their squad.

Environmental Hazards and Dynamic Events
The inclusion of extreme weather and interactive events, like rockets launching mid-game, enhances the unpredictability of matches and keeps the experience fresh.

Cons:

Limited Content at Launch
Battlefield 2042 launched with fewer maps and modes compared to previous titles. While the existing content is engaging, the lack of variety can make the game feel repetitive over time.

Performance Issues and Bugs
Despite patches, Battlefield 2042 still struggles with bugs and performance inconsistencies. Players on all platforms have reported glitches, crashes, and hit-registration issues that hinder the overall experience.

Specialist System Controversy
While innovative, the Specialist system received criticism from long-time fans who preferred the traditional class system. It sometimes makes teamwork feel less cohesive, as players may focus more on individual playstyles than squad objectives.

Lack of Key Features
Features such as a comprehensive scoreboard, voice chat at launch, and community-requested updates were missing, leaving the game feeling incomplete. Although updates have improved these aspects, the initial absence frustrated many players.

Conclusion:
Battlefield 2042 is an ambitious entry in the franchise, offering expansive maps, large-scale battles, and dynamic weather systems that deliver memorable moments. However, its rocky launch, performance issues, and divisive changes to core gameplay mechanics have overshadowed its potential. While subsequent updates have addressed some concerns, Battlefield 2042 remains a game that feels like it‚Äôs still finding its footing. For die-hard Battlefield fans, it‚Äôs worth exploring‚Äîbut it might not fully satisfy those looking for a polished experience from day one.

Recommendation: Wait for sales or further updates unless you're eager to jump into its massive multiplayer chaos.

If you want a classic Battlefield experience, go play BF2 or BF4, if you want something new and flashy, this game on sale is a decent choice. In short, the bad is the poor progression, high-end specs demand, vehicle camping and lack of teamwork.
The good however, oh my god it outweighs the negatives for me, the gunplay is responsive and smooth the movement is deep and can result in some extreme outplays even against aim training gods and the in-game attachment switch is honestly just amazing. Want to run in like an idiot with an M5? switch to a CQC setup and get a better chance, want to snipe with an smg? go ahead! I love it.
